Award.AwardTitle: Genomic Approaches to Understanding Cytokinin Signaling and Function in Rice
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Joseph Kieber (University of North Carolina - Chapel Hill)

CoPIs: G. Eric Schaller (Dartmouth College) and Ann Loraine (University of North Carolina - Charlotte)

Cytokinins are plant hormones that regulate many traits of agricultural importance, including the control of grain size and yield. In this project, genomic approaches will be used to uncover how cytokinin regulates growth and development in rice, using this plant species as a model to understand the regulation of grain size and yield in all cereals. Computational approaches will be used to interrogate and integrate the datasets generated by these studies. It is expected that these studies will illuminate the role of cytokinins in panicle development, and will provide specific information on how cytokinins regulate grain development in an agriculturally important crop. Because of conservation of gene sequence among cereals, information obtained from the study of rice may be applied to other agriculturally important species such as maize, wheat, barley, rye, and sorghum.

This project will enhance the infrastructure of research and education by providing training for undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers. A computation workshop will broaden the ability of the research community to use genomics resources. In addition, through partnerships with local groups including the Montshire Museum of Science (http://montshire.org/), programs aimed at fostering science education in grades K-12 will be created and maintained. Data will be made available through a public database (RiceCytokinin.org) as well as through long-term repositories such as the NCBI Short Read Archive (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/) and the Gene Expression Omnibus (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/). Germplasm generated in this project will be available upon request and through the USDA Genetic Stocks - Oryza (GSOR) Collection (http://www.ars.usda.gov/Main/site_main.htm?docid=18992&page=1).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The studies supported by this award focused on foundational studies of cytokinin signaling and action in rice and supported the development of tools that will continue to contribute to an understanding of rice growth and development. As part of this study we generated genomic datasets that define key aspects of the plant cytokinin response. First, we defined the cytokinin-regulated transcriptome in rice roots and shoots. Substantially more genes were regulated by cytokinin in the monocot rice as compared to those identified in prior studies performed with the dicot Arabidopsis. Of the genes regulated, we saw an overabundance of transcription factors, suggesting that cytokinin induces a transcriptional cascade upon perception. Second, we analyzed the expression of nearly all genes involved in cytokinin metabolism and signaling in the early developing rice inflorescence, this being the structure that plays a key role in establishing grain yield. Dynamic patterns of gene expression implicate subnetworks of genes in mediating cytokinin action during different stages of development, and point to how their manipulation could affect grain yield. Third, we performed a genome-wide analysis for DNA targets of a key transcription factor involved in cytokinin signaling, results from this analysis providing information on how cytokinin regulates multiple aspects of growth and development, as well as interactions with biotic and abiotic factors. We also defined the DNA-binding motifs for this family of transcription factors in vitro, and found the motifs to be conserved between monocots and dicots. The DNA-binding motifs were enriched at transcription factor binding sites as well as in promoters of cytokinin-regulated genes, consistent with their physiological significance. We generated and analyzed single and multiple loss-of-function alleles for cytokinin signaling elements in rice. These mutations altered cytokinin responsiveness, confirming that they play significant roles in mediating t cytokinin signaling. We have identified and characterized numerous effects of these mutations on rice growth and development, including novel effects on inflorescence and root architecture. Gain-of-function mutants in cytokinin signaling elements disrupted growth of inflorescences and roots, also pointing to the key role that cytokinin plays in regulating these agronomically significant traits.

 

Broader Impacts. Results from the proposed research benefited society through the development of a genome level understanding of a critical signaling pathway that regulates multiple traits of agronomic importance, including grain size and yield. Because of conservation of gene sequence among cereals, information obtained from the study of rice may be applied to other agronomically important species such as maize, wheat, barley, rye, and sorghum. The infrastructure of research and education was supported through programs aimed at multiple age groups. Hands-on research training included high-school students, undergraduates, Ph.D. students, and postdoctoral fellows. In addition, through partnerships with local groups, programs aimed at fostering science education were developed and maintained. We worked with AVA Art Gallery (Lebanon, NH) on six summer offerings of a Micro-Macro course for 9- to 12-year-olds, which integrates science with art projects. We worked with the Montshire Museum of Science (Norwich, Vt) on a plant-based "Lab Coat Investigation" aimed at elementary and middle school students, and on a cellular education unit which also makes loaner microscopes available to regional schools. We designed and presented a program at the UNC Science Expo focused on rice and the impact of cytokinin on yield. We participated in a Science in the Stacks program at UNC with presentations geared toward K-12 students, and Science in the News that includes monthly adult-oriented presentations about science topics currently popular in mainstream news. We produced daylong hands-on workshops introducing bioinformatics methods in 2013 and 2014 in North Carolina, and in 2017 at the Plant Biology meeting.
